Hi all,

good ideas you have, here are a couple of comments =>

It's not possible to tell from file names which job each arc file 
comes from?

During harvesting every job has its own directory but in the end one 
may place all arcs into a bigger pool for further processing. 

Would a series number be unique only inside a job so you could have 
files

name - 00001 - timestamp1 - IP.arc.gz
name - 00001 - timestamp2 - IP.arc.gz
name - 00001-  timestamp3 - IP.arc.gz
name - 00001 - timestamp4 - IP.arc.gz

produced by four different jobs. I somehow think a running series 
number in an archive implies that no two files in an archive have 
identical s-numbers (even if their timestamps differ)

S-number makes file names more unique but it's not very informative. 
Would it be possible to use job name instead 

OperatorGivenName - Jobname - Timestamp - IP.arc.gz for example =>

finland - photoarchives - timestamp - IP.arc.gz

Slight problem of course that job names have variable lengths unlike 
s-numbers.

kaisa


--- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@a...> 
wrote:
 
> An explanation:
> 
> For long-term inventory purposes, it is important ARCs
> have names that are descriptive and highly likely to be
> unique, and that they feature a header explaining the
> software that was used and ideally the 'crawl'/purpose
> that drove their collection. Current conventions don't
> always meet this need, though it's possible, within the
> existing formats.
> 
> NAMES:
> 
> Currently, Heritrix ARC names are of the form:
> 
> [operator-given-name][12-digit-timestamp]-[series#].arc.gz
> 
> We plan to change them to:
> 
> [operator-given-name]-[series#-padded-to-5-digits]-[12-digit-
timestamp]-[Base32-of-crawler-IP].arc.gz
> 
> By moving the series nmber before the timestamp, it is
> easier for people to work with shell-completion to
> enter a specific filename. But padding the series# to 5
> digits, sort order is preserved even when series
> numbers gain significant digits, up to 100,000 items
> (10TB at 100MB/arc).
> 
> By adding the crawl machine IP at the end uniqueness is
> nearly guaranteed. By representing the IP in Base32 the
> machine name will be much like a radio callsign -- more
> compact than dotted-decimal or hex, more memorable than
> 32-bit decimal number. IP is preferred to machine name
> as DNS info is more volatile and manipulable.
> 
> An ARC name under the new system might look like:
> 
>    CONGRESS-00007-20040420133907-FG71E2B.arc.gz
